summary: An internal FBI New York email chain from November 2019 discussing a training request for the 2019 National Training Institute (NTI) in Denver. The plenary session features attorney Brad Edwards presenting on 'Jeffrey Epstein and the Rights of His Victims.' The emails include cost estimates and approvals, and forward promotional material detailing Edwards' decade-long work representing Epstein's victims and his role in challenging the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.role: Attorney for Epstein victims, plenary speaker
persons.context: A nationally recognized trial lawyer specializing in representing victims of sexual abuse and violent crimes. He is scheduled to present at the 2019 NTI on his experience representing Epstein's victims and his litigation under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Billionaire sex offender arrested in July 2019 on federal charges for sex trafficking of minors. His 2008 non-prosecution agreement and subsequent 2019 arrest are central to the training presentation.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: Ruled in February 2019 that the federal government violated the rights of Epstein's victims by failing to confer with them prior to entering into the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: Brittany Henderson
persons.context: Mentioned as currently litigating alongside Brad Edwards to determine the remedy for the violation of the victims' rights in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Katy Maskolunas
persons.role: Director of events and special projects
persons.context: Contact person for the National Center for Victims of Crime regarding the NTI event.

connections.description: Edwards served as an attorney for multiple victims of Jeffrey Epstein, providing legal representation and investigating the case for over a decade.
Edwards and Henderson are currently litigating together on the next phase of the case to determine remedies for the violation of victims' rights.
Judge Marra ruled in favor of the legal argument advanced by Edwards, finding the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act in the Epstein case.

events.title: Epstein's initial plea deal
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in state court to charges of solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution after entering into a secret non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors.

events.title: Marra's CVRA ruling
events.description: US District Court Judge Kenneth Marra ruled that the federal government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to confer with Epstein's victims prior to entering into the 2008 non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Epstein's 2019 arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on federal charges for sex trafficking of minors in Florida and New York.

events.title: Epstein's death and case closure
events.description: The criminal case against Epstein was closed following his death.

events.title: 2019 National Training Institute (NTI)
events.description: Scheduled conference in Denver where Brad Edwards is to present a plenary session titled 'Jeffrey Epstein and the Rights of His Victims.'

keyFacts: FBI New York agents were seeking funding in November 2019 to attend a training where an attorney for Epstein victims, Brad Edwards, was presenting.
Brad Edwards' work, beginning in 2008, was crucial in keeping the Epstein case alive and ultimately paved the way for new charges in 2019.
A federal judge ruled in February 2019 that the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not conferring with Epstein's victims before the 2008 non-prosecution agreement.
Following Epstein's death, a hearing was held where sixteen victims delivered statements, which Edwards called 'a historic day for crime victims in the United States.'
The email chain reveals internal FBI budgetary considerations and approval processes for agent training related to high-profile cases.
